coursesTabContent.programIntro:
As a student in this 19-credit minor, you will first study the fundamentals of business, including accounting, marketing, management, and economics. Penn State World Campus then allows you to customize your minor by incorporating higher-level course work most appropriate to your career aspirations.
A grade of C or better is required in all courses that you take to fulfill requirements for the minor.
curriculumDescription:
To earn the minor, you must take 6 credits of 400-level Supporting Courses.
You must take at least 3 credits from the following list of courses:
ACCTG, BA, EBF, ECON, ENTR, FIN, HPA, IB, LHR, MIS, MGMT, MKTG, SCM, or STAT
For the remaining 3 credits, you may choose 3 credits from the original list of courses, or select 3 credits from the following list of courses:

If you're ready to see when your courses will be offered, visit our public
LionPATH course search (opens in new window)
to start planning ahead.

courses.title: Financial and Managerial Accounting for Decision-Making
courses.description: Introduction to the role of accounting numbers in the process of managing a business and in investor decision-making.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite MATH 021or 1.5 units of high school algebra
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introduction to Financial Accounting
courses.description: This course is an introduction to the basic concepts of financial accounting, including the collection, recording, summarization, and interpretation of accounting data.

courses.title: Introduction to Managerial Accounting
courses.description: This course emphasizes the use of accounting information for internal purposes (managerial accounting).

courses.title: Basic Management Concepts
courses.description: Study of fundamental principles and processes available to the understanding of management.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite (ENGL 15orENGL 30)and (ECON 102orECON 104)and (MATH 021or higher or satisfactory score on the mathematics placement examination)

courses.title: Principles of Marketing
courses.description: Covers terminology and important concepts related to marketing in the business environment. Domestic and international environments that impact marketing are included, with particular emphasis on the marketing environment, segmentation, positioning, and targeting.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ENGL 015orENGL 030;ECON 102orECON 104;MATH 021or higher or satisfactory score on the mathematics placement examination.

courses.title: Introductory Microeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: Methods of economic analysis and their use; price determination; theory of the firm; distribution.

courses.title: Introductory Macroeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: National income measurement; aggregate economic models; money and income; policy problems.

courses.title: Police Administration

courses.title: Advanced Business Writing
courses.description: Preparing and editing reports and presentations common to business, industry, and government.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Systems and Enterprise Integration
courses.description: Introductory course on integration of information technology into different venues, including the planning, development, and implementation of the integration.

courses.title: Development and Administration of Human Services Programs
courses.description: Fundamentals of program development and administration of human service programs in community settings; emphasis given to program content, strategies, and the overall planning process.

courses.title: Emerging Issues and Technologies
courses.description: Introduction to emerging issues, technology forecasting and analysis; overview of emerging issues and leading technologies in IST and how they impact information systems, users, the IT labor force and society.

courses.title: Legal and Regulatory Environment of Information Science and Technology
courses.description: Legal environment of information technology, constitutional/political issues, intellectual property, management, e-commerce, privacy, access, computer contracting, cyberspace regulation.

courses.title: Work Attitudes and Motivation
courses.description: Survey of theory and research with respect to attitudes, morale, and motivation of employees and management.

courses.title: Leadership in Work Settings
courses.description: Review of research and application of behavior principles in the areas of management and supervision.

coursesTabContent.programIntro: The 18 credits in this minor allow you to delve into the foundational concepts of criminal justice, as well as explore supporting topics and specializations within the field.
curriculumDescription: You must complete 6 of these 18 credits at the 400 level. A grade of C or better is required in all courses that you take to fulfill requirements for the minor.

If you're ready to see when your courses will be offered, visit our public
LionPATH course search (opens in new window)
to start planning ahead.

courses.title: Introduction to Criminal Justice
courses.description: Overview of the criminal justice system, including legal foundations, processing and correction of offenders, extent and types of crime, victims.

courses.title: Policing in America
courses.description: Police organization and operations in America.

courses.title: Courts and the Prosecution Process
courses.description: Purpose and function of criminal courts in society, organization, jurisdiction and staffing; prosecution, adjudication, and sentencing of offenders.

courses.title: Corrections in America
courses.description: Punishment and treatment of sentenced offenders, correctional institution organization, staffing, inmates, and subcultures.

courses.title: Interpersonal Communication
courses.description: This class is designed as an opportunity to explore the complexities of interpersonal communication and to develop a repertoire of interpersonal communication skills.

courses.title: Labor and Employment Relations Fundamentals
courses.description: The course surveys the main elements of modern labor and employment relations systems in the U.S. and beyond.

courses.description: Course foci center on contemporary theory and research, interpersonal communication in personal and professional relationships, and a research practicum in which students conduct an original research study.

coursesTabContent.programIntro: The 18-credit economics minor is composed of four required economics courses. You must also take a minimum of two additional 400-level ECON courses to complete the requirements for the minor. A grade of C or better is required in all courses that you take to fulfill requirements for the minor.
curriculumDescription:
Convenient and Flexible
Each course is taught using a blend of web technology, print, and other media to maximize flexibility while maintaining teacher and student interaction. As a Penn State World Campus student, you have the opportunity to learn when and where it's most convenient for you.

If you're ready to see when your courses will be offered, visit our public
LionPATH course search (opens in new window)
to start planning ahead.

courses.title: Introductory Microeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: Methods of economic analysis and their use; price determination; theory of the firm; distribution.

courses.title: Introductory Macroeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: National income measurement; aggregate economic models; money and income; policy problems.

courses.title: Intermediate Microeconomic Analysis
courses.description: Allocation of resources and distribution of income within various market structures, with emphasis on analytical tools.

courses.title: Intermediate Macroeconomic Analysis
courses.description: Analysis of forces that determine the level of aggregate economic activity.

courses.title: Decision Making and Strategy in Economics
courses.description: Development and application of the tools for decision making under uncertainty and for game theoretic analysis of economic problems.

courses.title: Economics of Public Expenditures
courses.description: Analytic and policy aspects of public expenditure decisions; applications from areas of contemporary public interest.

courses.title: Environmental Economics
courses.description: Environmental pollution, the market economy, and optimal resource allocation; alternative control procedures; levels of environmental protection and public policy.

courses.title: Advanced International Trade Theory and Policy
courses.description: Causes/consequences of trade; effects of tariffs and quotas; strategic trade policy; political economy of trade restrictions and other topics.

courses.title: International Finance and Open Economy Macroeconomics
courses.description: Trade balance movements, exchange rate determination; monetary and fiscal policies in open economies; international policy coordination; the world monetary system.

courses.title: Growth and Development
courses.description: Problems of capital formation, institutional considerations, theories of economic growth.

coursesTabContent.programIntro: The minor in energy business and finance is composed of 28–29 credits. Your required courses are in energy, business, and finance; energy and mineral engineering; and energy and geo-environmental engineering.
curriculumDescription:
Your elective courses will be selected from a list of available courses in energy, business, and finance; energy and mineral engineering; energy and geo-environmental engineering; geography; geosciences; and meteorology.
A grade of C or better is required in all courses that you take to fulfill requirements for the minor.

If you're ready to see when your courses will be offered, visit our public
LionPATH course search (opens in new window)
to start planning ahead.

courses.title: Introduction to Energy and Earth Sciences Economics
courses.description: Resource use decisions and their effect on local, national, and global development.

courses.title: Global Finance for the Earth, Energy, and Materials Industries
courses.description: The aim of this course is to introduce fundamental concepts of financial management and illustrate their global applications.

courses.title: Introductory Microeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: Methods of economic analysis and their use; price determination; theory of the firm; distribution.

courses.title: Geo-Resource Evaluation and Investment Analysis
courses.description: The course covers engineering evaluation of geo-resources, present value and rate of return analysis, mineral property and reserve estimation, and cost estimation and engineering economy concepts applied to geo-resources including energy and minerals.

courses.title: Elementary Statistics
courses.description: Descriptive Statistics, frequency distributions, probability and normal distributions, statistical inference, linear regression, and correlation.

courses.title: College Algebra II and Analytic Geometry
courses.description: Relations, functions, graphs; polynomial, rational functions, graphs; word problems; nonlinear inequalities; inverse functions; exponential, logarithmic functions; conic sections; simultaneous equations.

courses.title: Techniques of Calculus I
courses.description: Introduces and develops the mathematical skills required for analyzing change, and the underlying mathematical behaviors that model real-life economics and financial applications. Develops student knowledge of calculus techniques, and how to use a calculus framework to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 022or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination

courses.title: Calculus with Analytic Geometry I
courses.description: Introduces and develops the mathematical skills required for analyzing change and creating mathematical models that replicate real-life phenomena. Develops student knowledge of calculus techniques and how to use the calculus environment to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 22andMATH 26orMATH 26and satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination orMATH 40orMATH 41or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination.

courses.title: Energy and the Environment
courses.description: Energy utilization and technological development, energy resources, conversion and consequences on the local and global environment, and future energy alternatives.

courses.title: Energy Conservation for Environmental Protection
courses.description: Exposure to energy efficiency in day-to-day life to save money and energy, and thereby protect the environment.
courses.additionalInfo: GN The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Natural Sciences (GN) requirement.

courses.title: Oil: International Evolution
courses.description: Survey of the commercial development of the world petroleum industry from various international, historical, business, and cultural perspectives.

courses.title: Introduction to Electricity Markets
courses.description: Covers the structure of the electricity industry, regulatory institutions that oversee the industry, and the new market institutions that have been put into place since electricity restructuring.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite EBF 200 and MATH 140 and EBF 301 and (EBF 472 or STAT 200 or STAT 401 or ECON 106 or SCM 200 )

coursesTabContent.programIntro: You may select any combination of writing and/or literature courses that are relevant to your personal interests and professional goals. To complete this minor, you must complete 18 approved credits with a grade of C or better. You may not count courses used to satisfy the General Education Writing/Speaking requirement toward this minor.
curriculumDescription:
Select courses from the following options, to be taken during your third through eighth semesters:
6 credits from ENGL 200–299
6 credits from ENGL 400–499

This sample course list would fulfill the requirements for the minor.

The core courses enhance what you are learning in your major field of study and give you an understanding of the financial forces that affect business ventures.

The 18-credit Minor in Finance is composed of two required finance courses, plus four supporting courses selected from a list of available courses in accounting and finance in consultation with an adviser.

coursesTabContent.programIntro: The 18-credit Minor in Geography is composed of one prescribed and five elective courses. Your elective courses will be selected from a list of available courses in geography and can include a particular content emphasis, such as environmental issues or urban and regional planning.
curriculumDescription:
Requirements for the minor
—
18 credits chosen in consultation with a geography adviser:
Select 3 credits in physical geography (GEOG 1N or 3N or 30N or 430)
Select 3 credits in human geography (GEOG 1N or 2N or 3N or 30N or 430 or 432 or 438W)
Select 6 credits of additional geography courses (GEOG 1N or 2N or 3N or 6N or 430 or 432 or 438W)
Select 6 credits of 400-level geography courses (GEOG 430 or 432 or 438W)
All courses taken for the minor must be completed with a grade of C or higher.

If you're ready to see when your courses will be offered, visit our public
LionPATH course search (opens in new window)
to start planning ahead.

courses.title: Environment and Society in a Changing World
courses.description: Introduction to the relationships between humans and the natural environment, in addition to the theories and methods that geographers employ in addressing them.

courses.title: Global Parks and Sustainability
courses.description: This course uses parks and protected areas — both in the U.S. and globally — as a framework for exploring broad themes of sustainability, conservation, and socio-ecological systems.

courses.title: Apocalyptic Geographies: How can we prevent the end of the world?
courses.description: Explores various visions of the apocalypse and their relevance for addressing major contemporary social, ecological, and economic issues. These issues include global climate change, nuclear war, the growing refugee crisis, the breakdown of democratic governance, economic recession, and forms of everyday violence and social fracture.

courses.title: Food and the Future Environment
courses.description: Introduces students to the multiple connections of people and the environment through the dynamics of food and the places where it is produced, processed, and consumed.

courses.title: Maps and the Geospatial Revolution
courses.description: Explores the fundamentals of cartography, geographic information science, and associated technologies through mapping and spatial analysis to answer key human and environmental problems.

courses.title: Human Use of Environment
courses.description: The human use of resources and ecosystems and social causes and consequences of environmental degradation in different parts of the world; development of environmental policy and management strategies.

courses.title: Energy Policy
courses.description: Analysis, formulation, implementation, and impacts of energy-related policies, regulations, and initiatives.

courses.title: Energy Policy
courses.description: Analysis, formulation, implementation, and impacts of energy-related policies, regulations, and initiatives.

courses.title: Human Dimensions of Global Warming
courses.description: Human dimensions of global environmental change: human causes; human adaptations; and policy implications of global warming.

coursesTabContent.programIntro:
Penn State's history minor currently provides a wide range of instruction on topics such as early American history, including the American Revolution and the Civil War, as well as more focused courses on 19th-century Europe, World War II, and the modern United States.
At least 6 credits must be at the 400 level.
curriculumDescription:
If you're ready to see when your courses will be offered, visit our public
LionPATH course search (opens in new window)
to start planning ahead.

courses.title: American Civilization to 1877
courses.description: An historical survey of the American experience from its colonial beginnings through the Civil War and Reconstruction.

courses.title: American Civilization Since 1877
courses.description: An historical survey of the American experience from the emergence of urban-industrial society in the late nineteenth century to the present.

courses.title: The Roman Republic and Empire
courses.description: History of the Roman Republic and Empire from the origins of Rome to the disintegration of the Empire.

courses.title: History of Modern Europe Since 1789
courses.description: Political, social, and ideological developments; origin and impact of two World Wars; totalitarianism and democracy; changing role in the world.

courses.title: Introduction to the Civil War Era, 1848 through 1877
courses.description: Survey of the causes and consequences of America's deadliest conflict, the Civil War, from the end of the U.S.-Mexican War in 1848 through the end of Reconstruction in 1877.

courses.title: The World at War: 1939–1945
courses.description: In-depth study of the origins and conduct of World War II. Political and economic aspects as well as military.

courses.title: Introduction to the Middle East
courses.description: Origins of Islamic civilization; expansion of Islam; the Ottoman Empire; the Middle East since 1918.

courses.title: Undergraduate Seminar
courses.description: Involves a thematic or topical investigation with an emphasis on historical criticism and analysis; students will pursue the study of one historical topic in detail in this writing intensive course.

courses.title: The Holocaust
courses.description: In-depth study of the history of the Holocaust in Europe that puts special emphasis on primary sources.

courses.title: Recent American History
courses.description: Contemporary economic, social, and political aspects of the United States and its role as a world power since 1945.

courses.title: American Environmental History
courses.description: The history of the ways Americans have used and thought about the environment since 1500.

courses.title: History of Work in America
courses.description: A study of selected problems in the history of work in the United States, especially since 1877.

courses.title: History of Work in America
courses.description: A study of selected problems in the history of work in the United States, especially since 1877.

courses.title: History of Imperialism and Nationalism in Africa
courses.description: A selective overview of the history of imperialism and nationalism in Africa.

coursesTabContent.programIntro: The 18 credits of course work can inform you about such career aspects of homeland and security defense as emergency management, security administration, border security, and critical infrastructure protection.

If you're ready to see when your courses will be offered, visit our public
LionPATH course search (opens in new window)

courses.title: Introduction to Homeland Security
courses.description: An introduction to homeland security and defense, with a focus on policy, legal issues, organization, and administration.

courses.title: Introduction to Crisis and Emergency Management
courses.description: An introduction to emergency management in mitigating, preparing for, responding to, and recovering from hazards.

courses.title: Seminar in National Security Policy
courses.description: This course will examine the inter-relationship of foreign, military and economic policy.

courses.title: Homeland Security Intelligence
courses.description: The Homeland Security Intelligence course provides a depth of knowledge of key intelligence issues for homeland security professionals.

courses.title: The Politics of Terrorism
courses.description: Analysis of political terrorism as a violent alternative for peaceful change and traditional warfare in the nuclear age.

courses.title: The Intelligence Environment
courses.description: The course examines the users and processes of Intelligence Community, participants of Competitive Intelligence, and comparative intelligence communities.

coursesTabContent.programIntro:
To earn a minor in HDFS, you must complete 18 credits of HDFS course work with a grade of C or better.
As a student who minors in HDFS, you are encouraged to tailor the focus of your minor by selecting courses that fit your interests and complement your major area of study.
curriculumDescription:
Requirements of the minor include:
HDFS 129: Introduction to Human Development and Family Studies (3 credits)
9 credits of HDFS courses from any level
6 credits of 400-level HDFS courses

Note: As part of the course planning process, consult with an adviser as early as possible to be sure you will meet the prerequisites for courses you plan to use toward completion of the minor. For instance, with proper planning, completing HDFS 229 (which is a prerequisite of HDFS 428) can count toward the 9-credit block of HDFS courses from any level. Then, you will be eligible to take HDFS 428, which would count toward the 6-credit block of 400-level HDFS courses.

If you're ready to see when your courses will be offered, visit our public
LionPATH course search (opens in new window)
to start planning ahead.

courses.title: Introduction to Human Development and Family Studies
courses.description: Introduction to psychosocial and family development at all stages of the individual and family life cycle.

allSections.sectionDescription: At least 6 credits must be at the 400 level.

courses.title: Infant and Child Development
courses.description: Theory, research, and methods of social/behavioral/biological sciences related to developmental processes and intervention during infancy and childhood.

courses.title: Adolescent Development
courses.description: Social, behavioral, and biological development and intervention throughout adolescence.

courses.title: Adult Development and Aging
courses.description: Physiological, psychological, and social development and intervention from young adulthood through old age.

courses.title: Values and Ethics in Health and Human Development Professions
courses.description: Examines bases for choices among values in personal and professional relations in human development processes and supporting services.

courses.title: Human Development and Family Studies Interventions
courses.description: Survey of individual and family formal and informal intervention efforts; historical and current perspectives and approaches.

courses.title: Empirical Inquiry in Human Development
courses.description: Introduction to the skills involved in critical thinking in general and the methods of empirical inquiry in particular.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite a grade of C or better required inEDPSY 101orSTAT 200

courses.title: Family Development
courses.description: Family functions over the life course; family from a multidisciplinary perspective, emphasizing adaptation and change.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite HDFS 129 or3 credits in social, behavioral, or human biological sciences

courses.title: The Helping Relationship
courses.description: Theory and research related to interpersonal conditions which facilitate personal growth; intensive interpersonal competency training.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite (HDFS 311 andHDFS 312W)or 6 credits in human development and family studies or psychology

courses.title: Resolving Human Development and Family Problems
courses.description: Strategies for, and roles of professional specialists in, the solution of problems in human development and family functioning.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite HDFS 312W and6 credits in human development and family studies or psychology

courses.title: Family Relationships
courses.description: Dynamics of family interaction; effects of parenthood, sibling and intergeneration relationships on family solidarity.

courses.title: Infant Development
courses.description: Conceptual analysis, assessment, and empirical investigation of normal and deviant development, prenatal through first two years of life.

courses.title: Advanced Child Development
courses.description: Processes of development during childhood from birth to adolescence. Emphasis on theory, method, and empirical research.

courses.title: Developmental Transition to Adulthood
courses.description: Conceptual analysis and empirical investigation of interrelationships between developmental processes during the period of pubertal growth.

courses.title: Development and Administration of Human Services Programs
courses.description: Fundamentals of program development and administration of human service programs in community settings; emphasis given to program content, strategies, and the overall planning process.

coursesTabContent.programIntro: The 18-credit program includes courses covering organization of data, networking and telecommunications, and an introduction to information, people, and technology. You can choose additional courses from a variety of offerings, including IT project management, new media, and the web, as well as emerging issues and technology.
curriculumDescription: The IST minor — open to all interested undergraduate World Campus students who meet the prerequisites — could be a beneficial addition to almost any major.
To successfully complete the program, you must take at least 6 credits at the 400 level and receive a grade of C or above in all of the IST courses.

If you're ready to see when your courses will be offered, visit our public
LionPATH course search (opens in new window)
to start planning ahead.

courses.title: Information, People, and Technology
courses.description: The use, analysis, and design of information systems and technologies to organize, coordinate, and inform human enterprises.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Organization of Data
courses.description: Introduction to the concept of databases, including the storage, manipulation, evaluation, and display of data, and related issues.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Networking and Telecommunications
courses.description: Introduction to digital network topologies, transmission media, signal modulation, digital packet switching and routing, systems integration, communications management, and security.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Information and Organizations
courses.description: Overview of organizational structures and functions. Includes information processing and analytic perspectives of organizations.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite IST 210andIST 220
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: IT Project Management
courses.description: Exploration and application of the basic concepts, methodologies, and tools of project management in the field of information sciences and technology.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite IST 210andIST 220
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introduction to Application Development

coursesTabContent.programIntro: This 18-credit minor is available completely online. Your course work will include 9 to 12 credits from labor and human resources, along with 6 to 9 credits from business administration, economics, management, political science, psychology, or sociology. Six of your 18 credits must be at the 400 level.
curriculumDescription:
Convenient and Flexible
Each course is taught using a blend of web technology, print, and other media to maximize flexibility while maintaining teacher and student interaction. As a Penn State World Campus student, you have the opportunity to learn when and where it's most convenient for you.

400-Level LHR Courses (select 3 credits)
Take 3 credits of any 400-level LHR course during semesters 5 through 8.

Take 3 credits of any 400-level AFAM, CAS, ECON, HIST, LTNST, MGMT, PHIL, PSYCH, SPAN, SOC, or WMNST course during semesters 5 through 8, or select 3 credits from the following list in consultation with an adviser:

If you're ready to see when your courses will be offered, visit our public
LionPATH course search (opens in new window)
to start planning ahead.

courses.title: Exploring Work and Employment
courses.description: Introductory analysis of the employment relationship and the interrelated interests of management, workers, unions, and the public.

courses.title: Labor and Employment Relations Fundamentals
courses.description: The course surveys the main elements of modern labor and employment relations systems in the U.S. and beyond.

courses.title: Human Resources Fundamentals
courses.description: This course will provide students with an opportunity to understand and apply important concepts concerning human resources in the workplace.

courses.title: Employment Relationship: Law and Policy
courses.description: Examination of basic legal principles underlying the employment relationship, and their social, political, and economic bases.

courses.title: The Law of Labor-Management Relations
courses.description: Development of Anglo-American law regulating collective bargaining, with emphasis on American labor-management relations under Wagner, Taft-Hartley, and other acts.

allSections.sectionDescription: Take 3 credits of any 400-level AFAM, CAS, ECON, HIST, LTNST, MGMT, PHIL, PSYCH, SPAN, SOC, or WMNST course during semesters 5 through 8, or select 3 credits from the following list in consultation with an adviser:

courses.title: Financial and Managerial Accounting for Decision-Making
courses.description: Introduction to the role of accounting numbers in the process of managing a business and in investor decision-making.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 21or 1.5 units of high school algebra

courses.title: Living While Black: Themes in African American Thought and Experience
courses.description: Explore what it means to be Black in America by engaging with questions about identity and authenticity, freedom and unfreedom, radicalism and reform, gender and sexuality, and the role of music in African American life.
courses.additionalInfo: GS and US The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement and the United States Cultures (US) requirement.

courses.title: Social, Legal, and Ethical Environment of Business
courses.description: Explores the ethical, political, social, legal and regulatory, technological, and demographic diversity environment of business.
courses.additionalInfo: Note A student may not receive credit toward graduation for bothBLAW 243andBA 243.

courses.title: Interpersonal Communication
courses.description: This class is designed as an opportunity to explore the complexities of interpersonal communication and to develop a repertoire of interpersonal communication skills.

courses.title: Organizational Communication
courses.description: Examines the function and structure of communication in both formal and informal situations.

courses.title: Industrial Organization
courses.description: Focuses on the study of markets with imperfect competition.

courses.title: American Business History
courses.description: This course examines major developments in the history of modern American business and industry from the colonial period to the present.
courses.additionalInfo: GH and US The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Humanities (GH) requirement and the United States Cultures (US) requirement.

courses.title: Survey of Management
courses.description: Introduction to organizational factors relevant to management processes, including leadership, motivation, job design, technology, organizational design and environments, systems, change.

courses.title: Basic Management Concepts
courses.description: Study of fundamental principles and processes available to the understanding of management.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite (ENGL 15orENGL 30)and (ECON 102orECON 104)and (MATH 021or higher or satisfactory score on the mathematics placement examination)

courses.title: Leadership and Motivation
courses.description: Applies organizational behavior theories, concepts, and skills to leading and motivating individuals and groups.

courses.title: Introduction to Leadership
courses.description: This course introduces key leadership concepts and practices based on current theory and research. It is designed to help students to discover the knowledge and skills that are characteristic of effective leaders.

courses.title: Leadership Development: A Lifelong Learning Perspective
courses.description: The course examines the continuing influence of social and environmental factors in shaping leadership and leadership development.

courses.title: Communication Skills for Leaders in Groups and Organizations
courses.description: Theory- and research-based communication skills for leaders dealing with work-related problems in contemporary groups and organizations.

courses.title: Collective Decision-Making
courses.description: Application of theories of decision-making to work-related issues in groups and organizations requiring collective resolution and action.

courses.title: Race, Ethnicity, and Culture
courses.description: Focuses on historical patterns and current status of racial, ethnic and cultural groups and issues locally, nationally, and internationally.
courses.additionalInfo: GS and US The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement and the United States Cultures (US) requirement.

coursesTabContent.programIntro: The 18-credit Minor in Media Studies is composed of one required communications course and four elective courses selected in consultation with an adviser. At least 6 of your 18 credits must be at the 400 level. A grade of C or better is required in all courses that you take to fulfill requirements for the minor.
curriculumDescription:
If you're ready to see when your courses will be offered, visit our public
LionPATH course search (opens in new window)
to start planning ahead.

courses.title: The Mass Media and Society
courses.description: Mass communications in the United States: organization, role, content, and effects of newspapers, magazines, television, radio, books, and films.

courses.title: The Art of the Cinema
courses.description: The development of cinema to its present state; principles of evaluation and appreciation; examples from the past and present.

courses.title: Survey of Electronic Media and Telecommunications
courses.description: The development of electronic media and telecommunications, emphasizing social, economic, political and global impact.

courses.title: Gender, Diversity, and the Media
courses.description: Examines diversity, equity, and inclusion issues in media content, media business, and media practice.

courses.title: Law of Mass Communications
courses.description: Nature and theories of law; the Supreme Court and press freedom; legal problems of the mass media.

courses.title: Political Economy of Communications
courses.description: Structure and functions of American and other mass communications systems and their relationship to political and economic systems.

courses.title: News Media Ethics
courses.description: Ethical problems in the practice of journalism; principal public criticisms of news media; case study approach.

courses.title: International Mass Communications
courses.description: The role of international media in communication among and between nations and peoples.

courses.title: World Media Systems
courses.description: Comparative study of modern mass systems and the evolution and structure of specific countries' systems.

coursesTabContent.programIntro: The 18-credit organizational leadership minor consists of 12 credits of prescribed organizational leadership (OLEAD) courses and 6 credits of supporting and related topic areas, including business administration, communication arts and sciences, criminal justice, economics, history, labor studies and employment relations, philosophy, political science, psychology, sociology, and women's studies.
curriculumDescription:
If you're ready to see when your courses will be offered, visit our public
LionPATH course search (opens in new window)
to start planning ahead.

courses.title: Introduction to Leadership
courses.description: This course introduces key leadership concepts and practices based on current theory and research. It is designed to help students to discover the knowledge and skills that are characteristic of effective leaders.

courses.title: Organizational Theory and Functions for Leaders
courses.description: Examines the nature of organizations along with its various interconnected functions such as leadership, financial, communications, technology, production, sales, etc.

courses.title: Evidence-Based Leadership
courses.description: Starts by examining different kinds of evidence and analyzing their quality and usefulness; students can then learn how to use that evidence to improve their leadership.

courses.title: Communication Skills for Leaders in Groups and Organizations
courses.description: Theory- and research-based communication skills for leaders dealing with work-related problems in contemporary groups and organizations.

courses.title: Communication Skills for Leaders in Groups and Organizations
courses.description: Surveys the theory, research, and practice related to the communication processes by which individuals in groups and organizations exercise influence, whether or not they occupy positions of acknowledged leadership.

allSections.sectionTitle: Supporting Courses and Related Areas (select 6 credits)

courses.title: Introduction to Business
courses.description: A comprehensive view of the contemporary environment of business. This course provides a broad overview of the study of business and its environment, organization, operation, and interrelationships with government and society.

courses.title: Understanding Business Processes for LHR Professionals
courses.description: This course examines human resource management (HRM) and employment relations (ER) from a strategic perspective embedded in a complex and evolving organizational system.

courses.title: Emotional, Social, and Cultural Intelligences and the Implications for Leadership
courses.description: This course focuses on emotional intelligence, social, cultural intelligence competencies used to develop the leadership capacity to be self-aware, understand oneself and others, and to work across cultural differences to effectively meet the demands of work.

courses.title: Leadership Across Industries
courses.description: Compares and contrasts leadership in different types of industries. In this course students will learn about the various types of organizations and examine why leadership in those organizations have some leadership characteristics that are similar and others that are different.

courses.title: Leadership Development: A Lifelong Learning Perspective
courses.description: The course examines the continuing influence of social and environmental factors in shaping leadership and leadership development.

courses.title: Leadership Development: A Lifelong Learning Perspective
courses.description: The course examines the continuing influence of social and environmental factors in shaping leadership and leadership development.

courses.title: Leadership in a Global Context
courses.description: This course explores the science and practice of leadership around the globe through pertinent scholarly literature and related instructional resources.

courses.title: Women and Leadership
courses.description: Overviews scholarship relating to women in positions of leadership in groups and organizations, as well as obstacles to their success.

courses.title: Collective Decision-Making
courses.description: Application of theories of decision-making to work-related issues in groups and organizations requiring collective resolution and action.

courses.title: Collective Decision-Making
courses.description: Application of theories of decision making to work-related issues in groups and organizations requiring collective resolution and action.

courses.title: OLEAD Internship
courses.description: Supervised practicum in organizational leadership.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.description: Creative projects, including research and design, which are supervised on an individual basis and which fall outside the scope of formal courses.

coursesTabContent.programIntro:
The 18 credits of course work include at least one course in four of the five political science areas:
American politics
political theory
political methodology
comparative politics
international relations
Six of these 18 credits must be at the 400 level. A grade of C or better is required in all courses that you take to fulfill requirements for the minor.
curriculumDescription:
Convenient and Flexible
Each course is taught using a blend of web technology, print, and other media to maximize flexibility while maintaining teacher and student interaction. As a Penn State World Campus student, you have the opportunity to learn when and where it's most convenient for you.
Students are required to choose at least one course from each course list: American politics, international relations, comparative politics, and theory/methodology.

If you're ready to see when your courses will be offered, visit our public
LionPATH course search (opens in new window)
to start planning ahead.

allSections.sectionDescription: Students are required to choose at least one course from each course list: American politics, international relations, comparative politics, and theory/methodology.

courses.title: American Politics: Principles, Processes and Powers
courses.description: This course examines the American democracy by looking at the dynamic interaction between the founding ideals of the United States government, the institutions established by the Constitution, and the ongoing contest for power within and through those institutions.

courses.title: Rights in America
courses.description: This course explores the historical and contemporary struggles of particular groups within American society to expand their rights.

courses.title: Analyzing of Public Policy in the American States
courses.description: This course provides students with the tools to empirically evaluate policy proposals and outcomes in the American states.

courses.title: Analysis of Electoral Politics
courses.description: This course engages students in the empirical study of electoral politics in the United States.

courses.title: Analysis of Public Opinion and Political Attitudes
courses.description: This course engages students in the empirical study of public opinion.

courses.title: Politics and the Media
courses.description: An examination of how politics and public policy affect and are shaped by the news media, as a political institution, in America.

courses.title: American Constitutional Law
courses.description: The origins of judicial review, landmark decisions of the Supreme Court, and their impact on the American form of government.

courses.title: The American Legal Process
courses.description: Analysis of the roles, procedures, and policies characterizing the American legal system.

courses.title: American Judicial Behavior
courses.description: Analyzes behavior of judges and other participants in the legal process; examines how and why courts function as policymaking bodies.

courses.title: Congress and the Presidency
courses.description: Basic characteristics and processes of the national legislature and executive; roles and interaction of these institutions in the policy process.

courses.title: Policy Making and Evaluation
courses.description: Advanced analysis of public policy, emphasizing policy evaluation and the factors that determine policy success and failure.

courses.title: Contemporary Political Ideologies
courses.description: Critical analysis of contemporary political ideologies such as liberalism, conservatism, socialism, anarchism, fascism, feminism, and environmentalism.

courses.title: Introduction to Political Theory
courses.description: Introduction to basic issues in political theory through analysis of selected major political thinkers.

courses.title: Scientific Study of Politics
courses.description: This course introduces students to both the scientific study of politics and the way that study advances our understanding of political actors, events, processes, and institutions.

courses.title: Introduction to Political Research
courses.description: Introduction to conceptualization, research design, and measurement in political research.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite any 3 credits in political science

courses.title: Quantitative Political Analysis
courses.description: Data analysis and statistical applications in political research, including data processing, inferential statistics, contingency analysis, correlation and regression, and multivariate analysis.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite any 3 credits in political science

courses.title: Strategy and Politics
courses.description: Introduction to various methods of analyzing strategic behavior using social choice and game theories.

courses.title: Comparing Politics Around the Globe
courses.description: This course examines the variety of ways that people seek and wield power around the world. Through cross-national comparison and individual country analysis, the course considers different forms of democratic and authoritarian regimes, sources of stability and change in different regime types, and the relationship between cultural, economic, and social factors and political processes.

courses.title: Government and Politics of Europe
courses.description: This course introduces students to the politics and governing institutions of European countries through a historical and comparative perspective.

courses.title: Politics and Institutions of Latin-American Nations
courses.description: Social forces and processes, governmental institutions, foreign policies of major states of Latin America.

courses.title: International Relations
courses.description: Characteristics of modern nation-states and forces governing their international relations; nationalism; imperialism; diplomacy; current problems of war and peace.

courses.title: Strategy and Politics
courses.description: Introduction to various methods of analyzing strategic behavior using social choice and game theories.

courses.title: International Political Economy
courses.description: The transnational politics of trade, investment, aid, raw materials, and the environment; nation-states, multinational corporations, and the U.N.

courses.title: International Relations Theory
courses.description: A survey of traditional and contemporary conceptual frameworks and theoretical approaches for the analysis of international relations.

courses.title: National Security Policies
courses.description: Impact of national security on U.S. government and foreign policy; roles and interaction of President, Congress, government agencies, interest groups.

courses.title: The Politics of Terrorism
courses.description: Analysis of political terrorism as a violent alternative for peaceful change and traditional warfare in the nuclear age.

courses.title: American Foreign Policy
courses.description: Principles of American foreign policy; processes of policy formulation; roles of the President, Congress, the State Department, and other government agencies.

courses.title: International Relations of the Middle East
courses.description: The international relations of the Middle East, stressing national security policies of regional and outside actors, and major contemporary conflicts.

courses.description: This course engages students in the empirical study of public opinion.

courses.title: Politics and the Media
courses.description: An examination of how politics and public policy affect and are shaped by the news media, as a political institution, in America.

courses.title: American Constitutional Law
courses.description: The origins of judicial review, landmark decisions of the Supreme Court, and their impact on the American form of government.

courses.title: The American Legal Process
courses.description: Analysis of the roles, procedures, and policies characterizing the American legal system.

courses.title: American Judicial Behavior
courses.description: Analyzes behavior of judges and other participants in the legal process; examines how and why courts function as policymaking bodies.

courses.title: Congress and the Presidency
courses.description: Basic characteristics and processes of the national legislature and executive; roles and interaction of these institutions in the policy process.

courses.title: Policy Making and Evaluation
courses.description: Advanced analysis of public policy, emphasizing policy evaluation and the factors that determine policy success and failure.

courses.title: Contemporary Political Ideologies
courses.description: Critical analysis of contemporary political ideologies such as liberalism, conservatism, socialism, anarchism, fascism, feminism, and environmentalism.

courses.title: Introduction to Political Theory
courses.description: Introduction to basic issues in political theory through analysis of selected major political thinkers.

courses.title: Scientific Study of Politics
courses.description: This course introduces students to both the scientific study of politics and the way that study advances our understanding of political actors, events, processes, and institutions.

courses.title: Introduction to Political Research
courses.description: Introduction to conceptualization, research design, and measurement in political research.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite any 3 credits in political science

courses.title: Quantitative Political Analysis
courses.description: Data analysis and statistical applications in political research, including data processing, inferential statistics, contingency analysis, correlation and regression, and multivariate analysis.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite any 3 credits in political science

courses.title: Strategy and Politics
courses.description: Introduction to various methods of analyzing strategic behavior using social choice and game theories.

courses.title: Comparing Politics Around the Globe
courses.description: This course examines the variety of ways that people seek and wield power around the world. Through cross-national comparison and individual country analysis, the course considers different forms of democratic and authoritarian regimes, sources of stability and change in different regime types, and the relationship between cultural, economic, and social factors and political processes.

courses.title: Government and Politics of Europe
courses.description: This course introduces students to the politics and governing institutions of European countries through a historical and comparative perspective.

courses.title: Politics and Institutions of Latin-American Nations
courses.description: Social forces and processes, governmental institutions, foreign policies of major states of Latin America.

courses.title: International Relations
courses.description: Characteristics of modern nation-states and forces governing their international relations; nationalism; imperialism; diplomacy; current problems of war and peace.

courses.title: Strategy and Politics
courses.description: Introduction to various methods of analyzing strategic behavior using social choice and game theories.

courses.title: International Political Economy
courses.description: The transnational politics of trade, investment, aid, raw materials, and the environment; nation-states, multinational corporations, and the U.N.

courses.title: International Relations Theory
courses.description: A survey of traditional and contemporary conceptual frameworks and theoretical approaches for the analysis of international relations.

courses.title: National Security Policies
courses.description: Impact of national security on U.S. government and foreign policy; roles and interaction of President, Congress, government agencies, interest groups.

courses.title: The Politics of Terrorism
courses.description: Analysis of political terrorism as a violent alternative for peaceful change and traditional warfare in the nuclear age.

courses.title: American Foreign Policy
courses.description: Principles of American foreign policy; processes of policy formulation; roles of the President, Congress, the State Department, and other government agencies.

courses.title: International Relations of the Middle East
courses.description: The international relations of the Middle East, stressing national security policies of regional and outside actors, and major contemporary conflicts.

coursesTabContent.programIntro: The 18-credit course work, including the required introductory psychology course, allows you to choose a set of courses that match your specific area of interest.
curriculumDescription: The minor comprises 7 credits of core courses and 11 credits of elective courses, with 6 elective credits taken at the 400 level.
At least 6 of the 11 credits need to be at the 400 level in PSYCH.

If you're ready to see when your courses will be offered, visit our public
LionPATH course search (opens in new window)
to start planning ahead.

courses.title: Introductory Psychology
courses.description: Introduction to general psychology; principles of human behavior and their applications.
courses.additionalInfo: GS The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Basic Research Methods in Psychology
courses.description: Introduction to methods of psychological research, with special attention to hypothesis formation and testing, threats to validity, and data presentation.

allSections.sectionDescription: At least 6 of the 11 credits need to be at the 400 level in PSYCH.

courses.title: Introduction to Developmental Psychology
courses.description: Developmental principles; physical growth; linguistic, intellectual, emotional, and social development from infancy to maturity.

courses.title: Introduction to Social Psychology
courses.description: Introduction to Social Psychology discusses how people's thoughts, feelings, and behaviors are influenced by other people (real or imagined). The course will provide an overview of the field, potentially covering such topics as: attitudes, persuasion, person perception, automatic vs. conscious thought, the self, prosocial behavior, aggression, interpersonal attribution, conformity, obedience, culture, groups, prejudice and discrimination from a psychological perspective.

courses.title: Introduction to Personality Psychology
courses.description: Personality psychology involves examining theories of human nature and evaluating them in an empirical fashion.

courses.title: Introduction to Well-Being and Positive Psychology
courses.description: Applying psychological knowledge to develop and maintain effective personal adjustment and well-being and positive social relations.

courses.title: Introduction to Cognitive Psychology
courses.description: This course is an introduction to cognition, an area of psychology that investigates the ways in which we acquire, store, create and use knowledge.

courses.title: Neurological Bases of Human Behavior
courses.description: An introduction to biopsychology, emphasizing the structure and function of the human brain.

courses.title: Introduction to Abnormal Psychology
courses.description: This course focuses on some of the topics and questions people most commonly ask about psychology: What are the different psychological disorders, and what are they like? How do clinicians diagnose someone with a disorder? What do therapists actuallydoin therapy?

courses.title: Introduction to Industrial-Organizational Psychology
courses.description: Personnel selection, training, accident prevention, morale, and organizational behavior.

courses.title: Adolescence
courses.description: Physical, cognitive, and personality development during adolescence.

courses.title: Human Sexuality
courses.description: Psychological influences on human sexual behavior such as love, sexual orientation, gender, intercourse, contraception, sexually transmitted diseases, dysfunctions, and paraphilias.

courses.title: Applied Social Psychology
courses.description: Application of social psychological theories and research methods to field settings and to the study of social issues.

courses.title: Health Psychology
courses.description: Overview of the field with an emphasis on how psychological research contributes to an understanding of health and behavior.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PSYCH 100and 6 additional credits of PSYCH

courses.title: Abnormal Psychology
courses.description: Causes, dynamics, symptoms, and treatment of neuroses, psychoses, personality disorders, and other psychological disorders of adulthood.

courses.title: Selection and Assessment in Organizations
courses.description: Background in personnel testing, performance measurement, selection strategies, with emphasis on validity and measurement reliability.

courses.title: Work Attitudes and Motivation
courses.description: Survey of theory and research with respect to attitudes, morale, and motivation of employees and management.

courses.title: Leadership in Work Settings
courses.description: Review of research and application of behavior principles in the areas of management and supervision.

coursesTabContent.programIntro: The SRA minor is a 21-credit program with course work that exposes you to a variety of topics, including an introduction to security and risk analysis, threat of terrorism and crime, information security, and the legal and regulatory environment of privacy and security.
curriculumDescription:
The minor — open to all interested undergraduate World Campus students who meet the prerequisites — could be a beneficial addition to almost any major. To successfully complete the program, you must take at least 6 credits at the 400 level and receive a grade of C or better in all courses.
You can choose additional course work from areas that most interest you, including risk management and network security. Your academic adviser can help you select the area most in line with your interests.

If you're ready to see when your courses will be offered, visit our public
LionPATH course search (opens in new window)
to start planning ahead.

courses.title: Overview of Information Security
courses.description: Provides an understanding of the overview of information security including security architecture, access control, and internet secure applications.

courses.title: Introduction to Security and Risk Analysis
courses.description: This introductory course spans areas of security, risk, and analysis covering contexts in government agencies and business organizations.

courses.title: Threat of Terrorism and Crime
courses.description: Provides overview of nature, scope, and seriousness of threats to security as a result of terrorism and crime.

courses.title: Introduction to Application Development
courses.description: A first course in concepts and skills for application development.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite C or better inMATH 21or placement above the level ofMATH 21in the mathematics placement test.
Recommend preparation MATH 22
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introduction to Programming
courses.description: Fundamentals of computational thinking, including reasoning about problems at multiple levels of abstraction, and analyzing code for its behavior, efficiency, and correctness.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite MATH 21or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Networking and Telecommunications
courses.description: Introduction to digital network topologies, transmission media, signal modulation, digital packet switching and routing, systems integration, communications management, and security.

courses.title: Decision Theory and Analysis
courses.description: Provides an overview of decision theoretical and analytical concepts and tools in the security risk analysis field.

courses.title: Network Security
courses.description: Fundamental issues and concepts of network security, network security technologies and protocols, and emerging technologies in network security.

courses.title: Computer and Cyber Forensics
courses.description: Fundamental issues and concepts of computer forensics; aspects of computer and cyber crime; methods to uncover, protect, exploit, and document digital evidence; tools, techniques, and procedures to perform computer and cyber crime investigation.

courses.title: Information Security Management
courses.description: Contemporary security issues; security management processes, architecture, and models; risk analysis and management; security planning, analysis, and safeguards; security policies development and administration; contingency planning, incidence handling, and response; and security standards and certification processes.

courses.title: Legal and Regulatory Environment of Information Science and Technology
courses.description: Legal environment of information technology, constitutional/political issues, intellectual property, management, e-commerce, privacy, access, computer contracting, cyberspace regulation.

courses.title: Legal and Regulatory Environment of Privacy and Security
courses.description: Exploration of legal, regulatory, public policy, and ethical issues related to security and privacy for information technology professionals in public institutions, private enterprise, and IT services.

courses.title: Legal, Regulatory, Policy Environment of Cyber Forensics
courses.description: Legal, regulatory, and public policy environment of computer and network forensics that constrain investigatory and monitoring activities in computer and network environments.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite IST 110and sixth-semester standing or higher

courses.title: The Intelligence Environment
courses.description: The role of information and intelligence introduces students to the architecture and policies of the U.S. Intelligence Community (IC) and examines how U.S. intelligence policies and practices relate to overall U.S. foreign policy objectives and are influenced by today's global environment and emerging technologies. The course examines the users and processes of IC, participants of Competitive Intelligence, and comparative intelligence communities.

courses.title: Spatial Analysis of Risks
courses.description: Helps students develop a spatial perspective on risk analysis and empowers them with GIS spatial data representation, visualization, and analysis methods that are fundamental to the spatial analysis of risk.

courses.title: Informatics, Risk, and the Post-Modern World
courses.description: Provides in-depth study of how security informatics is influenced by the risk and post-modern culture.

courses.title: Crisis Informatics
courses.description: This course examines how information and communication technologies have played a role in saving lives, specifically in the areas of technologies used toward emergency response.

coursesTabContent.programIntro: The 18-credit course work includes the required Introductory Sociology course, along with elective courses that you may choose to match your specific area of interest.
curriculumDescription:
Convenient and Flexible
Each course is taught using a blend of web technology, print, and other media to maximize flexibility while maintaining teacher and student interaction. As a Penn State World Campus student, you have the opportunity to learn when and where it's most convenient for you.

If you're ready to see when your courses will be offered, visit our public
LionPATH course search (opens in new window)
to start planning ahead.

courses.title: Introductory Sociology
courses.description: The nature and characteristics of human societies and social life.
courses.additionalInfo: GS This course can be used to satisfy the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

allSections.sectionDescription: At least 6 credits must be at the 400 level.

courses.title: Criminology
courses.description: Explanations and measurement of crime; criminal law; characteristics of criminals and victims; violent, property, white-collar, organized, and sexual crimes.

courses.title: Sociology of the Family
courses.description: Family structure and interaction; functions of the family as an institution; cross-cultural comparisons.
courses.additionalInfo:
Note not currently available through World Campus
GS This course can be used to satisfy the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Race, Ethnicity, and Culture
courses.description: Focuses on historical patterns and current status of racial, ethnic and cultural groups and issues locally, nationally, and internationally.
courses.additionalInfo: GS This course can be used to satisfy the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Social Influence and Small Groups
courses.description: The study of social influence, leadership and status, and social cohesion and commitment processes in small groups.

courses.title: Work and Occupations
courses.description: Work and occupational life in modern society; work in the past, present, and future.

courses.title: Gender, Occupations, and Professions
courses.description: The role of gender in shaping contemporary North American patterns of employment, occupational roles, and statuses.

courses.title: Law and Society
courses.description: Law and Society studies the social origins of law and legal systems, occupational careers, and decision-making of legal officials.
